physical_appearance:This is a map featuring Malaya and Sumatra. On the bottom-left of the map
 there is a wider view of the region in a rectangular boxed section. The map utilises shades of brown and orange to indicate altitude. The map is deeply creased along the folds.

sgcool_label_text:These two map feature Malaya and Sumatra and belongs to Lung Chui Ying. They form part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was amassed by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012)
 who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee
 which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. \r\n\r\nForce 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.\r\n

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
These two map feature Malaya and Sumatra and belongs to Lung Chui Ying. They form part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was amassed by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.
